body: could you specify more clearly what your exact requirements are / how you think it should work?

to put it simply.

dynamically set the base_dn and search_dn
depending on the http header "host".

if i visit http://cloud.foo.com/ and http://cloud.bar.com/
with a single owncloud instance, i want to be able to
authenticate against the same ldap backend but with

dc=foo,dc=com for cloud.foo.com
and
dc=bar,dc=com for cloud.bar.com

make sense?

cheers
james


james mills / prologic

e: prologic@shortcircuit.net.au
w: prologic.shortcircuit.net.au

and using a second (and/or third and fourth and … ) ldap configuration is not suitable?

i could not find any documentation on how
a 2nd ldap configuration works (if at all).

does it match the 2nd/3rd/4th/etc configuration
against the http host header? or does it just try
reach successfully? if the later - this would not be
suitable. configurations need to be matched against something
like a specific domain name.

you can have a couple of configurations. they are more or less equal and they are tried one after the other (until it's successful, then the config is stored for the user). see http://doc.owncloud.org/server/5.0/admin_manual/configuration/auth_ldap.html

as i said this will simply not work as a solution for my use case.

i have two domains foo.com and bar.com
i want to be able to login to both via:
https://cloud.foo.com/ and https://cloud.bar.com/
using the same set of credentials but gain access
to different accounts.

i.e: same user name, different base_dn in the ldap tree.

if owncloud's ldap plugin only supports
multiple configurations and tries each in succession
then i'll only ever be able to login to the first account
on the first base_dn.

cheers
james


james mills / prologic

thanks for clarification.

i am thinking how this can be implemented reasonably. why would i assume it's correct to drop the subdomain instead of using it as dc=cloud,dc=foo,dc=com?

i believe a typical installation would mean
dc=foo,dc=com where the actual instance
is accessed by an apache configured virtualhost
such as owncloud.foo.com

also with regards to how it should work here are my thoughts.

1. add a "host:" field to the ldap configuration and a checkbox that if
ticked will perform the following:

if "match host" is enabled and configured host is not null
load the configuration whose host field matches the http host header.

something like this,

cheers
james

i rather think to allow a "magic" value for the base-dn field, e.g.
```
#http_host:2
```
where the number after the colon indicates how many parts of the host shall be transfered into the dc=name pattern.

then i also wonder, whether its necessary to allow only certain hosts, it could look like

```
#http_host:2{cloud.foo.com,cloud.bar.com}
```

then again, it somehow needs to work with user and group bases, too.

yet i am not fully convinced.

honestly i think the more explicit way is better.

match http host header against each
configuration and only use the configuration
that matches. giving the administrator
full control of the base_dn, search and group dns
for a particular incoming domain.

in my case i would setup two configurations.
one for dc=shortcircuit,dc=net,dc=au and
one for dc=mills,dc=io and the host field(s)
would be "mail.shortcircuit.net.au" and "mail.mills.io"
respectively.

cheers
james

there is already a host field, refering to the ldap host.
but yes, we could add one field in the settings (advanced → connection), though without checkbox. it's enforced when it is filled in, otherwise not. it will only be effective upon login. so it could be labeled "login only from host:". distinguishing users is done via mappings anyway, so it does not collide.

p.s.: maybe not "from host" but "addressing host" or something like it to avoid confusion that it restricts the user origin.

this is acceptable.
but probably call the field:

restrict configuration to virtualhost:

or simply

virtualhost:
(if non-empty will match this configuration when accessed via the hostname
above).

cheers
james
